case_name: Bhagwandas and Netram v. State of Rajasthan

facts.text: Bhagwandas and Netram are two brothers

anchor.surface_text: Bhagwandas and Netram are two brothers who along with Mt. Rameshwari, a daughter of the former,

facts.text: Mt. Rameshwari is a daughter of Bhagwandas

anchor.surface_text: Mt. Rameshwari, a daughter of the former,

facts.text: Bhagwandas, Netram and Mt. Rameshwari were tried by the Sessions Judge of Ganganagar for offence under s. 302 IPC and acquitted

anchor.surface_text: were tried by the Sessions Judge of Ganganagar for an offence under s. 302 of the Indian Penal Code but were acquitted.

facts.text: High Court of Rajasthan reversed acquittal of Bhagwandas and Netram, convicted them under s. 302 read with s. 34 IPC and sentenced to transportation for life

anchor.surface_text: On appeal to the High Court of Rajasthan, the order of acquittal of Bhagwandas and Netram was reversed and they were companyvicted under s. 302 read with s. 34 and sentenced to transportation for life.

facts.text: High Court affirmed acquittal of Mt. Rameshwari

anchor.surface_text: The order as to Mt. Rameshwari was affirmed and she was acquitted.

facts.text: Convicted persons obtained Special Leave to appeal under Art. 136 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: The companyvicted persons have obtained Special Leave to appeal under Art. 136 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Canal restarted flowing on May 5, 1953 after temporary closure

anchor.surface_text: According to the prosecution the canal after a temporary closure restarted flowing on May 5, 1953.

facts.text: Deceased Shivlal was allowed to take water to irrigate his fields although not his turn

anchor.surface_text: And although it was number his turn of water the deceased Shivlal was allowed to take the water to irrigate his fields.

facts.text: On May 6 canal flowing full capacity, Shivlal's turn 6 hours from 8 a.m. to 2 p.m.

anchor.surface_text: On May 6 the canal was flowing to its full capacity and Shivlal was to take his turn of water which was of 6 hours duration from 8 a.m. to 2 p.m.

facts.text: Shivlal watered lands from 8 a.m. to 10:30 a.m. to fill empty village diggi pond

anchor.surface_text: but he watered his lands from 8 a.m. to 10-30 a.m. because the village diggi  pond  which was empty had to be filled up.

facts.text: Mirab Ram Karan PW 1 with consent of Shivlal diverted water to fill diggi, promised remaining 3.5 hours after

anchor.surface_text: Mirab Ram Karan P.W. 1 with the companysent of Shivlal diverted the water for the purpose of filling up the diggi, promising him  Shivlal  to get him the rest of his turn of water, i.e. for 3 1/2 hours after the diggi had been filled up.

facts.text: Diggi filled up by 1 p.m. on the 7th

anchor.surface_text: The diggi was filled up by 1 p.m. on the 7th.

facts.text: Bhagwandas prevented Shivlal from diverting water to his field claiming it was his turn

anchor.surface_text: Shivlal then wanted to divert the water into his field but Bhagwandas prevented him from doing so claiming the turn to be his.

facts.text: Turn of Bhagwandas was after Surta whose turn was next to Shivlal according to Ram Karan Mirab PW 1

anchor.surface_text: According to Ram Karan Mirab P.W. 1 the turn of Bhagwandas was after Surta whose turn was next to that of Shivlal.

facts.text: Bhagwandas hit Shivlal on head with kassi after shouting enemy was going

anchor.surface_text: Bhagwandas thereupon shouted that the enemy was going and hit Shivlal on the head with a kassi.

facts.text: Netram hit Shivlal with lathi, Shivlal fell, both beat him; Mt. Rameshwari allegedly joined with wooden handle of kassi

anchor.surface_text: Netram then hit Shivlal with lathi as a result of which he fell down and then both beat Shivlal, and Mt. Rameshwari also, it was alleged, joined in this beating with a wooden handle of a kassi.

facts.text: Occurrence witnessed by Hazari PW 3 grazing camels in field of Surta

anchor.surface_text: This occurrence was witnessed by Hazari P.W. 3 who was grazing his camels in the field of Surta.

facts.text: Hazari shouted at assailants who left kassi and went away

anchor.surface_text: He went up to the place where the beating was going on and shouted to the assailants who went away leaving their kassi behind.

facts.text: Shivlal taken to Raisinghnagar by Bhaggu and Jagmal on she-camel to shop of Gyani Ram PW 4

anchor.surface_text: Shivlal was then taken to Raisinghnagar by Bhaggu and Jagmal on a she-camel to the shop of Gyani Ram P.W. 4.

facts.text: Shivlal told Gyani Ram that Bhagwandas, Netram and Rameshwari assaulted him due to water dispute

anchor.surface_text: There Shivlal told Gyani Ram also that Bhagwandas, Netram and Rameshwari had assaulted him because of the water dispute and also asked Gyani Ram to send for his son Ram Pratap and his Artya  Commission Agent  Ishardas.

facts.text: Ram Pratap came at about 6 p.m., Shivlal repeated story to him

anchor.surface_text: Ram Pratap came at about 6 p.m. Shivlal repeated the story to him and was then taken to the hospital by Jagmal, Bhaggu and others.

facts.text: Shivlal brought to hospital at 5 p.m., unconscious, treated by doctor PW 11, died on 8th at 8:15 a.m.

anchor.surface_text: At the hospital he was treated by the doctor P.W. 11 but died the following day  8th  at 8-15 a.m.

facts.text: First Information Report recorded on May 7 at 7:30 p.m. based on report Ex. P-1 by Ram Pratap s/o Shivlal

anchor.surface_text: The First Information Report was based on a written report Ex. P-1 by Ram Pratap s o Shivlal. It was recorded on May 7 at about 7-30 p.m.

facts.text: Shivlal had 15 injuries, injury No.1 sharp-edged grievous fatal, No.2 blunt grievous fatal

anchor.surface_text: According to the doctors evidence Shivlal was unconscious when he was brought to the hospital at 5 p.m. He had 15 injuries on his body, out of which injury No. 1 was with a sharp-edged weapon and injury No. 2 with a blunt weapon and both these injuries were grievous and were individually and companylectively fatal sufficient to cause death.

facts.text: Sessions Judge disbelieved prosecution evidence and acquitted accused

anchor.surface_text: The learned Sessions Judge disbelieved the whole evidence and acquitted the accused.

facts.text: High Court accepted testimony of Hazari PW 3 and dying declarations to Gyaniram PW 4 and Jora PW 7

anchor.surface_text: his testimony was accepted by the High Court. Both companyrts rejected the statement of Ram Pratap but the statements of Gyaniram and Jora were accepted by the High Court although they were rejected by the Sessions Judge. The High Court has relied upon the testimony of one eye witness Hazari P.W. 3 and two witnesses before whom Shivlal is alleged to have made two dying declarations.

facts.text: Supreme Court found evidence insufficient to warrant conviction, set aside High Court conviction

anchor.surface_text: In our view the evidence in the present case is of such quality and numberlegitimate inference of guilt of the accused companyld properly be drawn.

facts.text: No compelling reasons for High Court to reverse acquittal judgment

anchor.surface_text: The judgment of the High Court does number disclose any such reasons justifying interference with the findings of the trial Court.

s. 302 of the Indian Penal Code but were acquitted. On appeal to the High Court of Rajasthan, the order of acquittal of Bhagwandas and Netram was reversed and they were convicted under s. 302 read with s. 34 and sentenced to transportation for life. The order as to Mt. Rameshwari was affirmed and she was acquitted. The convicted persons have obtained Special Leave to appeal under Art. 136 of the Constitution. The appeal is founded on two grounds  1  that there was noevidence against the appellants sufficient to warrant a conviction and  2  that there were no compelling reasons for reversal of the judgment of acquittal.

under s. 302 read with s. 34 and sentenced to transportation for life. The order as to Mt. Rameshwari was affirmed and she was acquitted. The convicted persons have obtained Special Leave to appeal under Art. 136 of the Constitution. The appeal is founded on two grounds  1  that there was noevidence against the appellants sufficient to warrant a conviction and  2  that there were no compelling reasons for reversal of the judgment of acquittal. According to the prosecution the canal after a temporary closure restarted flowing on May 5, 1953. And although it was not his turn of water the deceased Shivlal was allowed to take the water to irrigate his fields.

The convicted persons have obtained Special Leave to appeal under Art. 136 of the Constitution. The appeal is founded on two grounds  1  that there was noevidence against the appellants sufficient to warrant a conviction and  2  that there were no compelling reasons for reversal of the judgment of acquittal. According to the prosecution the canal after a temporary closure restarted flowing on May 5, 1953. And although it was not his turn of water the deceased Shivlal was allowed to take the water to irrigate his fields. On May 6 the canal was flowing to its full capacity and Shivlal was to take his turn of water which was of 6 hours duration from 8 a.m. to 2 p.m.

dying declarations made to 3 persons and on the recovery of the kassi. They produced two eye witnesses Begaram P.W. 2 and Hazari P.W. 3. The dying declarations were made to three persons first to Jora P.W. 7, later to Gyaniram P.W. 4 at his shop and lastly to Ram Pratap P.W. 5 who arrived at the shop at 6 p.m. If the dying declaration was made to this witness it must have been at that time.

According to the doctors evidence Shivlal was unconscious when he was brought to the hospital at 5 p.m. He had 15 injuries on his body, out of which injury No. 1 was with a sharp-edged weapon and injury No. 2 with a blunt weapon and both these injuries were grievous and were individually and collectively fatal sufficient to cause death.

anchor.surface_text: This Court has held that the High Court should not set aside an acquittal unless there are substantial and compelling reasons for doing so. Surajpal Singh v. State 1952 S.C.R. 193, 201, Ajmer Singh v. The State of Punjab 1953 S.C.R. 418, 423, Aher Raja Khima v. The State of Saurashtra . The judgment of the High Court does not disclose any such reasons justifying interference with the findings of the trial Court.

The learned Sessions Judge was of the opinion that the evidence of the doctor P.W. 11 made the story that Shivlal could walk for a little distance upon the Khala of Hukma or was able to talk so as to make a dying declaration, improbable. But the learned Judges of the High Court disposed of this matter by saying that the doctor was comparatively young and that his statement was not in accord with the opinion expressed in books on Medical Jurisprudence by authors like Modi and Lyon.

anchor.surface_text: This Court has held that the High Court should not set aside an acquittal unless there are substantial and compelling reasons for doing so. Surajpal Singh v. State 1952 S.C.R. 193, 201, Ajmer Singh v. The State of Punjab 1953 S.C.R. 418, 423, Aher Raja Khima v. The State of Saurashtra . The judgment of the High Court does not disclose any such reasons justifying interference with the findings of the trial Court.

issues.text: Whether a dying declaration of the kind relied upon is by itself sufficient for sustaining a conviction on a charge of murder

anchor.surface_text: two dying declarations made by Shivlal to Gyaniram P.W. 4 and Jora P.W. 7. Besides the infirmities which the testimony of these two witnesses  Gyaniram P.W. 4 and Jora P.W. 1  suffered from due to material contradictions in their respective statements made at various stages of the case and which have been pointed out by the learned Sessions Judge who said about Gyaniram In such a state of affairs I refuse to put any weight and value to the statement of Gyaniram their evidence cannot be a sure foundation for maintaining the conviction if the statement of Hazari the sole eye witness is disregarded, as it must be disregarded in this case because ordinarily a dying declaration of the kind which the prosecution has relied upon is by itself insufficient for sustaining a conviction on a charge of murder.

anchor.surface_text: This Court in Sundarlal v. The State of Madhya Pradesh disapproved of Judges drawing conclusions adverse to the accused by relying upon such passages in the absence of their being put to medical witnesses. The learned Judges of the High Court were, therefore, in error in accepting the testimony of these witnesses in support of the correctness of the two dying declarations nor could the statement of the deceased alleged to have been made in the circumstances of this case be considered sufficient to support the conviction of the accused.

anchor.surface_text: There are apparent contradictions between the testimony of Hazari and Bega. The learned High Court Judges disposed of this by saying that Begas presence. on the spot is open to grave doubts. As such it is, in our opinion, not proper to contradict the statement of a man who was present on the spot by using the statement of another man who was in all probability not there. ... then it would detract so materially from his reliability that it would be dangerous to accept his testimony as being of any great value which is still more diminished by the finding as to the innocence of Mt. Rameshwari.

anchor.surface_text: But it cannot be said that the opinions of these authors were given in regard to circumstances exactly similar to those which arose in the case now before us nor is this a satisfactory way of disposing of the evidence of an expert unless the passages which are sought to discredit his opinion are put to him.
